title: 8  Groups and Numbers
text:
8.1 Basic Concepts
We first state, as a reminder, some results from Algebra that we shall be using in this chapter (though the proofs are omitted and will not be required).
This last property means that the result obtained from doing the arithmetic first and then reducing modulo \(m\) is the same as the result obtained by reducing all of the numbers modulo \(m\) first and then doing the arithmetic.
Euclid’s algorithm does two things of interest; it finds \(\greatcd (a, b)\) and it enables us to express this greatest common divisor in the form \((ma+nb)\) where \(m\) and \(n\) are integers.
An important property of \(\greatcd (a, b)\) is that it is the smallest positive integer which can be expressed in the form \(ma+nb\); this result is a corollary to the following theorem.
We have already been using the following concept, but we repeat the formal definition.
Pairs of integers which are relatively prime include (7, 11), (8, 9), (12, 55), (-14, 65). Pairs of numbers which are not relatively prime include (6, 6), (15, 126), (-4, 18). When asked to prove something about relatively prime numbers we often use the following fact.
Of fundamental importance in number theory is the class of numbers called prime numbers.
We refer to any positive integer that is not prime as composite. It is worth noting that if \(p\) is prime and \(a\) is any integer then the statement ‘\(p\) does not divide \(a\)’ is equivalent to saying that \(p\) and \(a\) are relatively prime (that is, \(\gcd (p, a)=1\)). This is not the case if \(p\) is not prime, for example 10 does not divide 18 but 10 and 18 are not relatively prime. The importance of the class of primes is a consequence of the following theorem which we state without proof.
The uniqueness property of a prime decomposition may seem obvious, but it depends on the number system. Of course who would have to first make precise what the definition of a ‘prime’ is in the new number system. Consider the following example.

title: 8  Groups and Numbers
text:
Let \(d, n \in \Z\), then \(d\) divides \(n\) if and only if \(n\) is an integer multiple of \(d\), that is, \(d \divides n\) if and only if \(\exists \, q \in \Z\) such that \(n=qd\).
If \(d \divides m\) and \(d \divides n\), then \(\forall \, a, b \in \Z\), we have that \(d \divides (am+bn)\).
Let \(d, n \in \Z, \, d>0\). Then \(\exists\) unique \(q, r \in \Z\) such that \(n=qd+r, \, 0\leq r<d\).
Let \(a=qb+r\), where \(a, b, q, r\) are all integers. Then \(d\) is a common divisor of \(a\) and \(b\) if and only if \(d\) is a common divisor of \(b\) and \(r\).
Let \(a=qb+r\), where \(a, b, q, r\) are all integers. Then \(\greatcd (a, b)= \greatcd (b, r)\). This is known as Euclid’s algorithm.
Let \(a, b, m\) be integers, \(m>0\). Then \(a\) is congruent to \(b\) modulo \(m\) if and only if \(m \divides (b-a)\). We denote this \(a \equiv b \modu m)\).
If \(a \equiv \ap \modu m)\) and \(b \equiv \bp \modu m)\), then

\(a+b \equiv \ap + \bp \modu m)\),
\(ab \equiv \ap \bp \modu m)\).




Example 8.1  

Consider: \[14 \times 7 \pmod{6} = 98 \pmod{6} \equiv 2 \pmod{6}.\] However \(14 \equiv 2 \pmod{6}\) and \(7 \equiv 1 \pmod{6}\), therefore \[14 \times 7 \equiv 2 \times 1 \pmod{6} \equiv 2 \pmod{6}.\]




Example 8.2 Find \(\greatcd (207, 567)\) and then find integers \(s\) and \(t\) such that \[\greatcd (207, 567) = 207s+567t.\]

Set \(a = 567\) and \(b=207\), then:
\[\begin{array}{r|l}
    a = 567 &  \\
    \underline{\phantom{blahhhhh}2b=414} & b = 207  \\
    {a- 2b =153} & \underline{a - 2b = 153\phantom{mm}}  \\
    \underline{\phantom{h}-2a + 6b = 108} & -a + 3b = 54  \\
    3a - 8b = 45 & \underline{3a - 8b = 45\phantom{mm}}  \\
    & -4a + 11b = 9  
\end{array}\]
Thus the greatest common divisor if 207 and 567 is 9; \(s=11\) and \(t = -4\).




Theorem 8.1 Let \(a\) and \(b\) be non-zero integers. Then, \[\{ma+nb \where m, n \in \Z\} = \{k \times \greatcd (a, b) \where k \in \Z \}.\]


Proof. Let \(S = \{ma+nb \where m, n \in \Z\}\) and \(T = \{k \times \greatcd (a, b) \where k \in \Z \}.\)

Let \(d = \gcd(a,b)\).
We first show that \(T \subseteq S\). We can find \(u,v \in \Z\) such that \(d = ua + vb\). Thus for any \(k \in \Z\), \(kd = (ku)a + (kv)b  \in S\).
Let \(m,n \in \Z\). Since \(d\) divides both \(a\) and \(b\), there are \(\alpha, \beta \in \Z\) such that \(a = d \alpha\) and \(b = d \beta\). It follows that \[ma + nb = (m\alpha) d + (n\beta) b = (m\alpha + n \beta)d \in T.\] Therefore \(S \subseteq T\).
We conclude that \(S =T\).



Corollary 8.1 Let \(a, b \in \Z\), \(S = \{ma+nb \where m, n \in \Z\}\). Then \(\greatcd (a, b)\) is the smallest positive integer in \(S\).


Proof. 

Let \(d = \gcd(a,b)\). By Theorem 8.1 \(S = \{kd: k \in \Z\}\). Clearly \(d\) is the smallest positive integer in \(\{kd: k \in \Z\}\) and so \(d\) is the smallest positive integer in \(S\).




Definition 8.1 (Relatively Prime) Two integers \(a\) and \(b\) are relatively prime if and only if \(\greatcd (a, b) = 1\).



Corollary 8.2 Two integers \(a\) and \(b\) are relatively prime if and only if there exist integers \(m\) and \(n\) such that \(ma+nb=1\).


Proof. 

If \(\gcd(a,b) = 1\), then we can find integers \(m,n \in \Z\) such that \(ma + nb =1\).
On the other hand, \(d = \gcd(a,b)\) is the smallest positive integer in the set \(S=\{ma +nb : m,n \in \Z\}\). If \(1 \in S\), then it is clear that \(d = 1\).



Corollary 8.3 If \(d \divides ab\) and \(d\) and \(a\) are relatively prime, then \(d \divides b\).


Proof. 

We can find \(m,n \in \Z\) such that \(1 = md + na\). It follows that \[b = b(md + na) = bmd + bna.\] Since \(d|ab\) and \(d|d\) we conclude that \(d| (bmd + abn)\). Therefore \(d|b\) as required.



Example 8.3 The numbers \(7\) and \(5\) are relatively prime hence if \(7\) divides \(5n\) for \(n \in \Z\), then \(7|n\).
Now consider \(6\) and \(15\). We have \(\greatcd(6,15) = 3\) and so \(6\) and \(15\) are not relatively prime. Observe that \(6|30\) but \(6\) divides neither \(2\) nor \(15\).



Definition 8.2 (Prime Number) A positive integer \(p\) is prime if and only if \(p>1\) and the only positive divisors of \(p\) are \(p\) and 1.



Theorem 8.2 (Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic) Let \(n\) be a natural number. If \(n \geq 2\) then \(n\) is uniquely expressible as a product of primes (except for reordering).


Proof. Omitted.


Example 8.4 Some examples

\(42= 2 \times3 \times 7\)
\(64 = 2^6\)
\(100 = 2^2 \times 5^2\)
\(101\) is prime.




Example 8.5 Consider the even integers \(2\Z\). What are the primes? We consider a positive integer \(m \in 2\Z\) prime if it is a not composite. Using this definition, the primes in \(2\Z\) are \[\{2(2k+1): k \ge 0\} = \{2,6,10,14 \ldots \}.\]
It is clear that any element of \(2\Z\) can be factorised as a product of primes. Indeed any element of \(2\Z\) which is not prime is of the form \(2^i m\) for some \(m \in \{2(2k+1): k \ge 0\} = \{2,6,10,14 \ldots \}.\)
Do we have unique factorisation into primes? Take the number \(36\). This can be factorised either as \(2 \times 18\) (both of which are prime with our definition) or as \(6 \times 6\). Therefore we do not have unique factorisation.
Perhaps we have the wrong definition. What if we stick with Definition 8.2 unchanged. With this definition of prime, the only element of \(2\Z\) that is prime is \(2\). In this case we do not always have a factorisation into primes! Indeed any even integer that is not a power of \(2\) cannot be factorised as a product of primes in \(2\Z\).


Theorem 8.3 Let \(a, b, m \in \Z\). Then \(\greatcd (a, m) = 1\) and \(\greatcd (b, m) = 1\) if and only if \(\greatcd (ab, m) = 1\).


Proof. 

Suppose \(\gcd(a,m) = \gcd(b,m) = 1\). There are numbers \(u,v,s,t \in \Z\) such that \(ua + vm= sb + tm =1\). it now follows that \((ua +vm)(sb + tm) =1\). Expanding: \[(ua +vm)(sb+tm) = (as)ab + m(atu + bsv + mtv) = 1.\] It follows that \(1\) is the smallest positive integer in \(\{j(ab) + km : j,k \in \Z\}\). Therefore \(\gcd(ab,m) = 1\) as required.
On the other hand suppose that \(\gcd(ab,m) = 1\). Then \(1\) is the smallest positive integer in \(\{j(ab) + km : j,k \in \Z\}\). However, \(\{j(ab) + km : j,k \in \Z\} \subseteq \{j'a + k'm : j',k' \in \Z\}\) and \(\{j(ab) + km : j,k \in \Z\} \subseteq \{j'b + k'm : j',k' \in \Z\}\) . Therefore \(1\) is the smallest positive integer in each of \(\{j'a + k'm : j',k' \in \Z\}\) and \(\{j'b + k'm : j',k' \in \Z\}\). Therefore \(\gcd(a,m) = \gcd(b,m) = 1\) as required.

title: 8  Groups and Numbers
text:
8.2 Reduced Residue System
In the Algebra module we explored the idea of congruence modulo some positive integer \(n\). It is worth reminding ourselves of the definition:

Definition 8.3 (Congruence) Let \(n \in \N\) and let \(a,b \in \Z\). We say \(a\) is congruent to \(b\) modulo \(n\), and write \(a \equiv b \pmod{n}\), to mean that \(n \divides (a-b)\).


Example 8.6  


\(15 \equiv 1 \pmod{7}\) since \(7| (15-1)\);
For any integer \(x\) and any positive integer \(n\), \(x \equiv x \pmod{n}\) as \(n | (x-x)\).



It should be clear that for some given \(n\) there will be an infinite number of integers congruent to some fixed \(a\) modulo \(n\) and that we can group those integers together in a set. This is best illustrated by example.

Example 8.7  

Let \(a = 2\) and \(n=5\). Then:
\[\begin{eqnarray*}
2 &\equiv & 2 \pmod{5} \\
7 &\equiv & 2 \pmod{5} \\
12 &\equiv & 2 \pmod{5} \\
-3 &\equiv & 2 \pmod{5}.
\end{eqnarray*}\]


This leads to the following definition.

Definition 8.4 (Residue Class) Let \(a, n\) be integers, \(n\) positive. The residue class of \(a\) modulo \(n\) is denoted and defined by \[[a]_n = \{ m \where m \in \Z, m \equiv a \modu n) \} = \{a+kn \where k \in \Z \}.\]


Example 8.8  

\[\begin{eqnarray*}
[1]_{5} &=& \{\ldots, -14,-9,-4,1,6,11,\ldots\} \\
{[3]}_{7} &=& \{\ldots, -11,-4,3,10,17,\ldots \} \\
{[0]}_{4} &=& \{\ldots, -12,-8,-4,0,4,8,\ldots\}.
\end{eqnarray*}\]








Aside




Consider \(H = \{ 5k : k \in \Z\}\). This is a subgroup of \((\Z,+)\). Notice that the left coset of \(H\) containing \(1\) is precisely the left coset
\[1H= \{ 1 + h : h \in H\} = \{ 5k + 1 : k \in \Z \} = \{\ldots, -14,-9,-4,1,6,11,\ldots\}  = [1]_{5}.\] So the left coset of \(H\) containing \(1\) is the residue class of \(1\) modulo \(5\). Notice that \(H\) is precisely \([0]_{5}\).
This is not a coincidence.
Let \(n\) be a positive integer. Then \(H = \{ nk : k \in \Z \}\) is a subgroup of \((\Z,+)\). For any integer \(a \in \Z\), the left coset \(aH\) of \(H\) containing \(a\) is precisely \[\{a + h \in h \in H\} = \{ a + nk : k \in \Z \} = [a]_{n}.\] Clearly \(H = [0]_{n}\).



Notice that grouping together in sets the integers that are congruent to each other modulo some given \(n\) results in a partitioning of the integers such that each integer appears in exactly one of the residue classes. This partitioning of \(\Z\) is a direct consequence of the fact that congruence modulo \(n\) is what is known as an equivalence relation on a set (more of this in third-year Group Theory).

Example 8.9  

We take \(n = 5\). Then:
\[\begin{eqnarray*}
[0]_{5} &=& \{\ldots, -10, -5, 0, 5, 10, \ldots\} \\
{[1]}_{5} &=& \{\ldots, -9, -4, 1, 6, 11, \ldots\} \\
{[2]}_{5} &=& \{\ldots, -8, -3, 2, 7, 12, \ldots\} \\
{[3]}_{5} &=& \{\ldots, -7, -2, 3, 8, 13, \ldots\} \\
{[4]}_{5} &=& \{\ldots, -6, -1, 4, 9, 14, \ldots\}.
\end{eqnarray*}\]



Lemma 8.1 Every integer is in exactly one of the residue classes \([0]_n, [1]_n, \ldots ,[n-1]_n\) for a given positive integer \(n\).


Proof. 

We note that for \(i\) between \(0\) and \(n-1\) and \(a \in \Z\), \(a \in [i]_{n}\) precisely when \(a\) has remainder \(i\) when divided by \(n\). Therefore every integer belongs to one of the residue classes \([0]_n, [1]_n, \ldots ,[n-1]_n\).


Recall that when we first introduced the concept of \(\Z_n\), we defined this to be the set \(\{0, 1, 2, \ldots , n-1 \}\). Strictly speaking, we should have defined \(\Z_n\) as \[\Z_n = \{[0]_n, [1]_n, [2]_n, \ldots , [n-1]_n \},\] though for practical purposes we tend to use the former representation.

Definition 8.5 Let \(A, B \in \Z_n\) (so \(A\) and \(B\) are residue classes, not numbers). Choose \(a \in A\) and \(b \in B\). Then

\(A+B = [a+b]_n\) or, equivalently, \([a]_n + [b]_n = [a+b]_n\),
\(A \times B = [ab]_n\) or, equivalently, \([a]_n[b]_n = [ab]_n\).


Note that this is a set with two binary operations defined on it. This forms the triple \((\Z_n, +, \times)\) and such a structure is called a ring, provided that certain axioms are satisfied. We shall see more of this in the final chapter.

Example 8.10  

Take \(n = 5\). Then \(\Z_{5} = \{[0]_{5}, [1]_{5}, [2]_{5}, [3]_{5},[4]_{5}\}\). We compute

\([1]_{5} + 2_{5} = [1 + 2]_{5} = [3]_{5}\);
\([3]_{5}[4]_{5} = [3\times 4]_{5} =  [2]_{5}\).



It is important to check that these operations are well defined. That is, if we were to choose different members of \(A\) and \(B\), say \(\ap\) and \(\bp\) instead of \(a\) and \(b\) respectively, does \([\ap + \bp]_n = [\ap]_n + [\bp]_n\) and does \([\ap \bp]_n = [\ap]_n[\bp]_n\)? The fact that the answer is in the affirmative follows from statement (g) in the introductory section to this chapter.

Lemma 8.2 \((\zn, +)\) is an abelian group.


Proof. 

This is clear from the definition of \(+\) on \(\zn\).


Suppose that we now change the binary operation on \(\zn\) from addition modulo \(n\) to multiplication modulo \(n\). Let us take \(\Z_5\) as an example and construct the operation table (in all of the following examples we shall, for convenience, write \(a\) in place of \([a]_n\)).

\[\begin{array}{c|ccccc}
\otimes_5&0&1&2&3&4\\
\hline
0&0&1&2&3&4\\
1&0&1&2&3&4\\
2&0&2&4&1&3\\
3&0&3&1&4&2\\
4&0&4&3&2&1
\end{array}\]

As we can see, \((\Z_5, \times)\) cannot be a group as the element 0 has no inverse; recall that under multiplication the identity element is 1 and in the table above it is clear that there does not exist an element of \(\Z_5\), \(a\) say, such that \(0 \times a = a \times 0 = 1\). So what if we remove 0 from the set and consider \((\Z_5 \backslash \{0\}, \times)\)? It should be clear, from an examination of the table above, that this results in the following group (check the axioms):
\[\begin{array}{c|cccc}
\otimes_5&1&2&3&4\\
\hline
1&1&2&3&4\\
2&2&4&1&3\\
3&3&1&4&2\\
4&4&3&2&1
\end{array}\]
The obvious question to ask at this point is whether or not this process works for all \(n \in \N\). Consider \((\Z_8 \backslash \{0\}, \times)\):

\[\begin{array}{c|ccccccc}
\otimes_8&1&2&3&4&5&6&7\\
\hline
1&1&2&3&4&5&6&7 \\
2&2&4&6&0&2&4&6 \\
3&3&6&1&4&7&2&5 \\
4&4&0&4&0&4&0&4 \\
5&5&2&7&4&1&6&3 \\
6&6&4&2&0&6&4&2 \\
7&7&6&5&4&3&2&1
\end{array}\]

Clearly this does not form a group for two reasons. First, the set is not closed under \(\otimes_8\) and, second, not all elements have an inverse in the set (1, 3, 5, and 7 have inverses in the set, but 2, 4, and 6 do not). Notice, also, that it is the non-invertible elements that cause the system to be not closed. So, what if we were to remove the elements that have no inverse in the set? \[\begin{array}{c|cccc}
\otimes_8&1&3&5&7\\
\hline
1&1&3&5&7\\
3&3&1&7&5\\
5&5&7&1&3\\
7&7&5&3&1
\end{array}\] This system now forms a group. But what is the relationship between the elements of \(\zn\) that have no inverse and \(n\) itself? On the face of the above example, it looks like we simply remove the even numbers from the set. However, if we consider \((\Z_{12}\backslash \{0\}, \times)\), in order for that to be a group we need to remove the elements 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 9, and 10. So how do we identify the invertible elements in \(\zn\)? The answer comes from the following definition:

Definition 8.6 (Reduced Residue System) The reduced residue system modulo \(n\) is denoted and defined by \[\znx = \{ \, [a]_n \in \zn \where \exists \, [b]_n \in \zn \, \text{s.t.} \, [a]_n[b]_n = [1]_n \, \}.\]


Theorem 8.4 For any positive integer \(n\), \(\znx\) is an abelian group.


Proof. 

If \(\znx\) is a group then it must be an abelian group since the product is commutative. We therefore verify that \(\znx\) forms a group under multiplication.

Closure:

Let \([a]_{n},[b]_{n} \in \znx\). Then there are elements \([a']_{n},[b']_{n} \in \zn\) such that \([a]_{n}[a']_{n} = [1]_[n] = [b]_{n}[b']_{n}\). Now consider \([ab]_{n}\). Observe \[[ab]_{n}[a'b']_{n} = [(ab)(a'b')]_{n} = [1]_{n}\] since \(ab \equiv 1 \pmod{n}\) and \(a'b' \equiv 1 \pmod{n}\).

Assoociativity:

Let \([a]_n,[b]_n,[c]_{n} \in \znx\). Then, \[\begin{eqnarray*}
([a]_n[b]_{n})[c]_{n} &=& [ab]_{n}[c]_n \\
&=& [(ab)c]_{n} \\
&=& [a(bc)]_{n}\\
&=&[a]_{n}[bc]_{n}\\
&=& [a]_{n}([b]_{n}[c]_n).
\end{eqnarray*}\]

Identity:

It is clear that \([1]_n \in \znx\) is the identity element.

Inverses:

Let \([a]_n \in \znx\). By definition, there is an element \([a']_{n} \in \zn\) such that \([a]_{n}[a']_{n} = [1]_n\). Notice that \([a']_{n}[a]_{n} = [1]_{n}\) also. It follows that \([a']_{n} \in \znx\) and every element \([a]_{n} \in \znx\) has an inverse in \(\znx\).




One consequence of the definition is that we can characterise \(\znx\) in a different way, namely as the set of all positive integers less than \(n\) that are relatively prime to \(n\) (from here on in we shall, in general, use a single representative of a residue class to represent the class itself). Note, however, that this is not an alternative definition, just a convenient way of ‘seeing’ \(\znx\). One advantage of this characterisation is that it makes it easy to identify the elements in the set and, hence, to determine the size of the set (more of that later).

Example 8.11 The elements of \(\Z_{15}^{\times}\) are the positive integers that are relatively prime to 15. \[\Z_{15}^{\times} = \{1, 2, 4, 7, 8, 11, 13, 14\}\] and the operation table is \[\begin{array}{c|cccccccc}
\otimes_{15}&1&2&4&7&8&11&13&14\\
\hline
1&1&2&4&7&8&11&13&14\\
2&2&4&8&14&1&7&11&13\\
4&4&8&1&13&2&14&7&11\\
7&7&14&13&4&11&2&1&8\\
8&8&1&2&11&4&13&14&7\\
11&11&7&14&2&13&1&8&4\\
13&13&11&7&1&14&8&4&2\\
14&14&13&11&8&7&4&2&1
\end{array}\]

What we have discussed above leads to the following corollary.

Corollary 8.4 \((\zn \backslash \{[0]_n\}, \times)\) is a group if and only if \(n\) is prime.


Proof. 

\(\Rightarrow\): Suppose \((\zn \backslash \{[0]_n\}, \times)\) is a group. Suppose \(n = pq\) for some positive integers \(p,q \le n\). If \(p,q < n\), then \([p]_n,[q]_{n} \in \zn \backslash \{[0]_{n}\}\) and \[[p]_{n}[q]_{n} =[pq]_{n}= [n]_{n} = [0]_{n}.\] This is a contradiction since, by assumption, \((\zn \backslash \{[0]_n\}, \times)\) is a group and so it is closed under time. It follows that one of \(p\) and \(q\) is equal to \(n\) and the other is equal to \(1\). Thus the only divisors of \(n\) and \(1\) and itself — \(n\) is prime.
\(\Leftarrow\): If \(n\) is prime then \(\znx = \zn \backslash \{[0]_{n}\}\) (by the alternative characterisation above). Therefore, \((\zn \backslash \{[0]_n\}, \times)\) is a group since it is precisely \((\znx, \times)\).



Example 8.12  

Write down the elements of \(\Z^{\times}_{20}\) and \(\Z^{\times}_{24}\).

We have \[\Z^{\times}_{20} = \{1,3,7,9,11,13,17,19\}\] and \[\Z_{24}^{\times} = \{1,5,7,11,13,17,19,23\}.\]

Classify, according to the Fundamental Theorem of Finite Abelian Groups, all of the abelian groups of order 8.

We decompose \(8 = 2^3\). This gives isomorphically distinct abelian groups \[\Z_{4}, \Z_4 \times \Z_2, \Z_2 \times \Z_2 \times \Z_2.\]

The groups in (a) are isomorphic to which of the groups in (b)?

The group \(Z^{\times}_{20}\) has elements of order \(4\) and none of order \(8\) and so must be isomorphic to \(\Z_{4}\times \Z_{2}\); for \(Z^{\times}_{24}\) all of its elements have order \(2\) and so it is also isomorphic to \(\Z_{2}\times \Z_{2}\times \Z_{2}\).




Example 8.13  

List the elements of \(\Z^{\times}_9\).

\[\Z_9^{\times} = \{1,2,4,5,7,8,\}.\]

Show that this group is isomorphic to \(\Z_6\).

We need only show that \(\Z_9^{\times}\) is cyclic. Indeed it is generated by \(2\), and also by \(5\).

Find two distinct isomorphisms between \(\Z^{\times}_9\) and \(\Z_6\).

The two distinct isomorphisms arise from the two different generators:

\(\theta_1: \Z_9^{\times} \to \Z_6\) by \(\theta_1(2^{i}) = i\) for \(0 \le i \le 5\);
\(\theta_2: \Z_9^{\times} \to \Z_6\) by \(\theta_2(5^{i}) = i\) for \(0 \le i \le 5\).

We note that \(\theta_1 \ne \theta_2\) since \(\theta_1(5) = 5\) and \(\theta_2(5) = 1\).

title: 8  Groups and Numbers
text:
8.3 Applications to Number Theory
In the last part of this chapter we shall examine how we can use our knowledge of groups to solve problems in number theory and, in particular, we shall be studying three theorems, namely Fermat’s Little Theorem (FLT), Euler’s Theorem, and Wilson’s Theorem. It is hoped that this very short review of number theoretic problems will not only convince you of the power of the abstract algebra that we have studied to date, but also whet your appetite for the third-year Number Theory and Cryptography module.
We begin with a statement of Fermat’s Little Theorem.

Theorem 8.5 (Fermat’s Little Theorem) Let \(p\) be a prime and let \(a\) be any integer such that \(p\) does not divide \(a\). Then \[a^{p-1} \equiv 1 \modu p).\]


Proof. 

First we note that if \(p\) does not divide \(a\), then \([a]_{p} \in \Z_{p}^{\times}\) (\(a\) is co-prime to \(p\)).
The result is now a consequence of Theorem 4.1. We can see this as follows: \(|\Z_{p}^{\times}| = p-1\) since \(\Z_{p}^{\times}= \Z_{p}\backslash\{[0]_{p}\}\). Now Theorem 4.1 states that the order of \([a]_{p}\) divides \(|\Z_{p}^{\times}|\). It follows that \(([a]_{p})^{p-1} = [a^{p-1}]_{p} = [1]_{p}\). Thus \(a^{p-1} \equiv 1 \pmod{p}\).



Example 8.14 What is the principal remainder on dividing \(6^{82}\) by 17?

Solution:
Observe that \(17\) is prime and so we can make use of Fermat’s Little Theorem to simplify this calculation. Write \(82 = (5 \times 16) + 2\). Then \(6^{82} = (6^{16})^{5} \times 6^2\). By FLT, \(6^{16} \equiv 1 \pmod{17}\). Therefore, \[(6^{16})^{5} \times 6^2 \equiv 6^2 \pmod{17} \equiv 2 \pmod 17.\]



Example 8.15 Show that, for every positive integer \(n\), the number \(n^{33}-n\) is divisible by 15.

First observe that \(n^{33}-n = n(n^{32}-1)\). Next observe that \(15| n^33 - n\) if and only if both \(5\) and \(3\) divide \(n^{33} -n\). Since 5 and 3 are prime we can make use of FLT. We show that both \(5\) and \(3\) divide \(n(n^{32}-1)\).

\(3|(n^{33}-n)\): If \(3\) divides \(n\) we are done. If \(3\) does not divide \(n\), then \(n\) and \(3\) are relatively prime. Write \(32 = 2\times 16\). Then \[n^{32} \equiv (n^2)^{16} \equiv 1 \pmod{3}\] by FLT. Therefore \(n^{32} -1 \equiv 0 \pmod{3}\) and \(3|(n^32 -1)\).
\(5|(n^{33}-n)\): If \(5\) divides \(n\) we are done. If \(5\) does not divide \(n\), then \(n\) and \(5\) are relatively prime. Write \(32 = 4\times 8\). Then \[n^{32} \equiv (n^4)^{8} \equiv 1 \pmod{5}\] by FLT. Therefore \(n^{32} -1 \equiv 0 \pmod{5}\) and \(5|(n^32 -1)\).



The obvious question to ask is whether we can generalise the above result to include composite moduli. Consider the conditions that apply for FLT to work; first, we work modulo a prime, second we have that \(p\) does not divide \(a\). Recall that if \(p\) is prime the statement \(p\) does not divide \(a\) is equivalent to saying that \(p\) and \(a\) are relatively prime. So, a naive approach to extending the theorem to composite numbers would be to conjecture as follows:

Let \(a\) and \(n\) be integers such that \(\greatcd (a, n)=1\). Then \(a^{n-1} \equiv 1 \modu n)\).

Does this work?

This does not work. A counterexample is as follows: take \(n = 4\) and \(a=3\). Then \(\gcd(a,n) = \gcd(3,4) =1\). However \[3^{3} \equiv 3 \pmod{4}.\]

So, is there a way in which we can generalise FLT to cover non-prime moduli? The answer is ‘yes’ and the solution lies in considering the exponent of \(a\); if we are raising \(a\) to the power of \(p-1\), where \(p\) is prime, that is the same as raising it to the power of the order of \(\Z_p^{\times}\) since this group has \(p-1\) elements (a fact that was used in our proof of FLT). We consider, then, raising \(a\) to the power of the order of \(\znx\) where \(n \in \N\) and working modulo \(n\).

Definition 8.7 (Euler Totient Function) Let \(m, n \in \N\). The Euler totient function, denoted \(\phi\), is the function \(\phi : \N \rightarrow \N\) defined by \[\phi (n) = | \, \{m \in \N \where m \leq n \, \text{and} \, \greatcd (m, n)=1 \} \, |, \;\; \forall \, n \in \N.\]

Note that this is, in fact, \(| \znx |\).

Example 8.16  

\(\phi(30) = |\{1,7,11,13,17,19,23,29\}| = 8\).


We can now generalise FLT to include composite moduli as follows:

Theorem 8.6 (Euler’s Theorem) Let \(n \in \N\) and \(a \in \Z\) such that \(a\) and \(n\) are relatively prime. Then, \[a^{\phi(n)} \equiv 1 \modu n).\]


Proof. 

The proof is almost identical to the proof of FLT. The key ingredient is once more Lagrange’s Theorem.
Let \(a \in \Z\) such that \(\gcd(a,n) =1\). Then \([a]_{n} \ne [0]_{n}\) and \([a]_{n} \in \znx\). Now as \(|\znx| = \phi(n)|\), we have, by Lagrange’s Theorem that \[([a]_{n})^{\phi(n)} = [1]_{n}.\] Therefore \(a^{\phi(n)} \equiv 1 \pmod{n}\) as required.


Hopefully, the success or failure of our chosen attempts to generalise FLT will now make complete sense.

Let us revisit the \(n=4\) and \(a =3\) example. Notice that \(\phi(4) = 2\) and \(3^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{4}\).

This function, together with Euler’s Theorem, prove to be extremely useful tools in solving number-theoretic problems.

Example 8.17 Find the unit digit of \(3^{101}\).

Notice that if \(d \in \{0,1,\ldots, 9\}\) is the unit digit of \(3^{101}\), then \(3^{101} \equiv d \pmod{10}\) since there is a \(q \in \Z\) such that \(3^{101} = 10q + d\). We use Euler’s Theorem to compute \(d\). Note that \(\phi(10) =|\{1,3,7,9\}| =  4\) and \(101 = 4 \times 25 + 1\). It follows that \[3^{101} = (3^{4})^{25} \times 3) \equiv 1 \times 3 \pmod{10}.\] The last digit of \(3^{101}\) is therefore \(3\).


The function \(\phi : \N \rightarrow \N\) has some remarkable properties. But, given \(n \in \N\), how do we calculate \(\phi (n)\)? If \(n\) is large it will be very time consuming to investigate all of the natural numbers less than \(n\) to establish which are relatively prime to \(n\). We might hope for a formula to allow us to calculate \(\phi (n)\) for any \(n \in \N\), but where do we start in trying to find such a formula? The following table lists \(\phi (n)\) for \(1 \leq n \leq 30\):

There does not appear to be a pattern, except that \(\phi (n)\) appears to always be even for \(n>2\)… to find out more you need to sign up for third-year Number Theory and Cryptography!
Notice the very close link between FLT and Euler’s Theorem.

FLT is a corollary of Euler’s Theorem: if \(p\) is prime, \(\phi(p) = p-1\) and so for \(a \in \Z\) relatively prime to \(p\), \(a^{\phi(p)} = a^{p-1} \equiv 1 \pmod{p}\).

It is worth noting that Euler’s totient function and Euler’s Theorem are central to a cryptosystem called RSA, an algorithm for public-key cryptography, developed in 1977, that relies on the prime factorisation of extremely large integers and which is used for, inter alia, encrypting credit card data during purchases over the internet. Again, more of that in third-year Number Theory and Cryptography.
We conclude our very brief survey of applications of group theory to number theory with an investigation. You realise that this is trivial since \(n! \equiv 0 \modu n)\) for all natural numbers \(n\) so, determined to find something more interesting (and still waiting for someone to invite you out), you decide to investigate the relationship between \((n-1)!\) and itself modulo \(n\). Some rapid calculations yield the following table:

Satisfied, you postulate that there is a relationship between \((n-1)!\) and itself modulo \(n\) if \(n\) is prime. You have discovered Wilson’s Theorem.

Theorem 8.7 (Wilson’s Theorem) If \(p\) is prime, then \((p-1)! \equiv -1 \modu p)\).


Proof. 

We begin with the following observation. Let \(1 \le x \le p-1\) and suppose that \(x\) is its own inverse in \(\Z_{p}^{\times}\). This means that \(x^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{p}\). Rearranging, \(x^2 -1 \equiv 0 \pmod{p}\). Therefore \(p|(x^2-1)\). Using the difference of two squares \(p|((x-1)(x+1)\). Since \(p\) is prime either \(p|(x-1)\) or \(p|(x+1)\). Thus \(x \equiv \pm 1 \pmod{p}\). Since \(1 \le x \le p-1\), then \(x = 1\) or \(x =p-1\). Thus \(x \in \Z_{p}^{\times}\backslash\{1,p-1\}\), the inverse of \(x \in \Z_{p}^{\times}\) is not equal to \(x\). For \(2 \le x < p-1\) write \(x^{-1}\) for the element of \(y \in \{2,3,\ldots, p-2\}\) such that \(xy \equiv 1 \pmod{p}\). Thus we can find elements \(x_1, x_2 ,\ldots, x_{\left(\frac{p-3}{2}\right)} \in  \{2,3,\ldots, p-2\}\) such that
\[(p-1)!  = 1\times (x_1 \times x_1^{-1})\times (x_2\times x_2^{-1}) \ldots \left(x_{\left(\frac{p-3}{2}\right)} x_{\left(\frac{p-3}{2}\right)}^{-1}\right) \times (p-1).\]
Working modulo \(p\), we have \[\begin{eqnarray*}
(p-1)!  &=& 1\times (2 \times 2^{-1})\times (3\times 3^{-1}) \ldots \left(\left(\frac{p-1}{2}\right) \left(\frac{p-1}{2}\right)^{-1}\right) \times (p-1) \\
&\equiv& 1\times 1 \times 1 \ldots 1 \times (p-1) \pmod{p} \\
&\equiv& (p-1) \pmod{p} \\
&\equiv& -1 \pmod{p}
\end{eqnarray*}\]
as required.



Example 8.18 Arrange the integers \(2, 3, \ldots , 11\) into pairs \((a\times b)\) satisfying \(ab \equiv 1 \modu 13)\).

Solution: We have \[(2\times 7)(3 \times 9)(4 \times 10)(5 \times 8)(6 \times 11).\]



Example 8.19 Find the principal remainder when 15! is divided by 17.

We use Wilson’s Theorem: \(16! = 16 \times 15! \equiv -1 \pmod{17}\). It follows that \(15! \equiv (-1) (16)^{-1}\pmod{17}\). Since \(16\) is its own inverse in \(\Z_{17}^{\times}\). It follows that \(15! \equiv -16 \pmod{17}\); \(15! \equiv 1 \pmod{17}\). The principal remainder when \(15!\) is divided by 17 is therefore 1.



Example 8.20 Find the inverses of 10, 9 and 8 in \(\Z_{11}^{\times}\) and hence find the remainder when 7! is divided by 11.

We note that \(10 \equiv -1 \pmod{11}\) and so \(10\) is its own inverse i \(\Z_{11}\).
Now \(9 \equiv -2 \pmod{11}\). Therefore \[9 \times 5 \equiv -10\pmod{11} \equiv 1 \pmod{11}\] and so \(9^{-1} = 5\)
Lastly \(8 \equiv -3 \pmod{11}\) and so \[8 \times -4 \equiv 12 \pmod{11} \equiv 1 \pmod{11}.\] It follows that \(8^{-1} = 7\).
We apply Wilson’s Theorem to compute the remainder of \(7!\) when divided by \(11\). We have: \[10! = 10 \times 9 \times 8 \times 7! \equiv -1 \pmod{11}.\] Therefore \[7! \equiv -(10^{-1}\times 9^{-1}\times 8^{-1})\pmod{11}.\] Hence \[7! \equiv 35 \pmod{11}\equiv 2 \pmod{11}.\]



Example 8.21 Use Wilson’s Theorem to find the principal remainder on dividing 51! by 61.

Applying Wilson’s Theorem: \[51! \equiv -(60 \cdot 59 \cdot \ldots \cdot 52)^{-1}\pmod{61}.\] Now we use the fact that \[60 \equiv -1 \pmod{61}, 59 \equiv -2\pmod{61}, \ldots, 52 \equiv -9\pmod{61}.\] Therefore \[60 \cdot 59 \cdot \ldots \cdot 52 \equiv  -(9!) \pmod{61}.\]
Now \(9! = 7! \times 72\). We decompose \(7! = 7 \times 60 \times 12\). Thus \[7! \equiv - 84 \pmod{61} \equiv 38 \pmod {61}.\] On the other hand \(72 \equiv 11 \pmod {61}\). Therefore \(9! \equiv 38 \times 11 \pmod{61} \equiv 52 \pmod{61}\).
Now we compute \(52^{-1} \in \Z_{61}^{\times}\). We use the fact that \(52 \equiv -9 = -3 \times 3 \pmod{61}\). Now \(3^{-1} \in \Z_{61}^{\times}\) is \(-20\). Therefore \[(-9)^{-1} = (-3)^{-1}\times 3^{-1} \equiv 20 \times -20 = 27 \pmod{61}.\]
It follows that \(51! \equiv 9! \equiv 27 \pmod{61}\).


It is worth noting that the converse of Wilson’s Theorem is also true (it is, in fact, an if and only if statement), that is if \((p-1)! \equiv -1 \modu p)\) then \(p\) is prime. This is, however, not much use as a primality test!

title: 8  Groups and Numbers
text:
8.4 Problem Sheet 8
Covers Chapter 8.




Question 8.1



Use Euclid’s algorithm to find the greatest common divisor of 440 and 189. Then find integers \(s\) and \(t\) such that \(\text{gcd}(440, 189) = 189s + 440t\).
Use Euclid’s algorithm to find the greatest common divisor of 1343 and 391. Then find integers \(s\) and \(t\) such that \(\text{gcd}(1343, 391) = 1343s + 391t\).
Use Euclid’s algorithm to find the greatest common divisor of 975 and 121. Then find integers \(s\) and \(t\) such that \(\text{gcd}(975, 121) = 121s + 975t\).






Show Solution 8.1




Solution 8.1


First recall the general principle: \[
\mbox{if} \,\,\, a = qb + r \,\,\,\mbox{then} \,\,\, \mbox{gcd}\,(a,
b) = \mbox{gcd}\,(b, r).
\]

In what follows we repeat that procedure at each step. \[\begin{align}
440 &= 2 \times 189 + 62 \tag{1}\\
189 &= 3 \times 62 + 3 \tag{2}\\
62 &= 20 \times 3 + 2 \tag{3}\\
3 &= 1 \times 2 + 1 \tag{4}\\
2 &= 2 \times 1 \tag{5}
\end{align}\] So, gcd \((440, 189)=1\).
We can now work backwards from the gcd as follows: \[\begin{eqnarray*}
1 &=& 3 - (1 \times 2)\\
&=& 3 - (62 - (20 \times 3)) \hspace{5cm} \text{using} \quad (3)\\
&=& (21 \times 3) - (1 \times 62)\\
&=& (21 \times (189 - (3 \times 62))) - (1 \times 62) \hspace{2.5cm} \text{using} \quad (2)\\
&=& (21 \times 189) - (64 \times 62)\\
&=& (21 \times 189) - (64 \times (440 - (2 \times 189))) \hspace{2cm} \text{using} \quad (1)\\
&=& (-64 \times 440) + (149 \times 189).
\end{eqnarray*}\]
So \(s = 149\) and \(t = -64\).
We compute \(\gcd(1343,391)\):
\[\begin{align}
1343 &= 3 \times 391 + 170 \tag{6}\\
391 &= 2 \times 170 + 51 \tag{7}\\
170 &= 3 \times 51 + 17 \tag{8}\\
51 &= 3 \times 17 \tag{9}
\end{align}\]
So, gcd \((1343, 391)=17\).
We can now work backwards from the gcd as follows: \[\begin{eqnarray*}
17 &=& 170 - (3 \times 51)\\
&=& 170 - (3 \times (391 - (2 \times 170))) \hspace{3.1cm} \text{using} \quad (7)\\
&=& (7 \times 170) - (3 \times 391)\\
&=& (7 \times (1343 - (3 \times 391))) - (3 \times 391) \hspace{2cm} \text{using} \quad (6)\\
&=& (7 \times 1343) - (24 \times 391).
\end{eqnarray*}\]
So \(s = 7\) and \(t = -24\).
We compute \(\gcd(-419,52)\):
\[\begin{align}
975 &= 8 \times 121 + 7 \tag{10}\\
121 &= 17 \times 7 + 2 \tag{11}\\
7 &= 3 \times 2 + 1 \tag{12}\\
2 &= 2 \times 1 \tag{13}
\end{align}\]
So, gcd \((975, 121)=1\).
We can now work backwards from the gcd as follows: \[\begin{eqnarray*}
1 &=& 7 - (3 \times 2)\\
&=& 7 - (3 \times (121 - (17 \times 7))) \hspace{4cm} \text{using} \quad (11)\\
&=& (52 \times 7) - (3 \times 121)\\
&=& (52 \times (975 - (8 \times 121))) - (3 \times 121) \hspace{2.3cm} \text{using} \quad (10)\\
&=& (52 \times 975) - (419 \times 121).
\end{eqnarray*}\]
So \(s = -419\) and \(t = 52\).








Question 8.2


Use your result from Question 8.1 c. to find the inverse of \([121]_{975}\) in \(\Z^{\times}_{975}\).





Show Solution 8.2




Solution 8.2


Note that, by Euclid, gcd\((a, b) = ma +nb\) for some \(m, n \in \Z\). So, if gcd\((a, b) = 1\) we have that \(ma = 1 - nb\) and so \(a\) divides \(1 - nb\). It then follows, by definition, that \(nb \equiv 1 \modu a)\). Consequently we must have that \([n]_a = [b]_a^{-1}\).
We found in 1(c) above that \((52 \times 975) - (419 \times 121) = 1\). Hence \([121]^{-1}_{975} = [-419]_{975} = [556]_{975}\).







Question 8.3


Show that \(\Z^{\times}_{12}\) is isomorphic to \(\Z_2 \times \Z_2\) and write down an isomorphism between the two groups.





Show Solution 8.3




Solution 8.3


\(\Z^{\times}_{12} = \{1, 5, 7, 11\}\), a group of order 4.
We know that there are only two isomorphically distinct groups of order 4, namely \(\Z_4\) and \(\Z_2 \times \Z_2\). We also know that \(\Z_4\) is cyclic , whereas \(\Z_2 \times \Z_2\) is not. So, in order to show that \(\Z^{\times}_{12}\) is isomorphic to \(\Z_2 \times \Z_2\), we simply need to demonstrate that it is not cyclic. The easiest way to do this is to show that \(\Z^{\times}_{12}\) does not contain any element of period 4 (if the group is cyclic it must have a generator which must have a period equal to the order of the group). Note that
\[\begin{eqnarray*}
5^2 &=& 25 \equiv 1 \modu 12)\\
7^2 &=& 49 \equiv 1 \modu 12)\\
11^2 &=& 121 \equiv 1 \modu 12).
\end{eqnarray*}\]
Hence every element has period 2, except for the identity which has period 1. So \(\Z^{\times}_{12}\) is isomorphic to \(\Z_2 \times \Z_2\) and not \(\Z_4\).
As every element of each of those two groups (identity excepted) has period 2, an isomorphism is not difficult to find. For example \[\theta = \left(\begin{array}{cccc}(0, 0)&(0,1 )&(1, 0)&(1, 1)\\1&5&7&11\end{array} \right).\]







Question 8.4


Use Fermat’s Little theorem to find the principal remainder on dividing:

\(5^{25}\) by 13;
\(17^{44}\) by 7;
\(19^{53}\) by 11.






Show Solution 8.4




Solution 8.4


Recall Fermat’s Little Theorem (FLT):
If \(p\) is prime and \(a\) is an integer such that \(p \nmid a\), then \(a^{p-1} \equiv 1 \modu p)\).

In the notation of FLT let \(p=13\) and \(a = 5\). Now, \(13 \nmid 5\), so by FLT we have that \(5^{12} \equiv 1 \modu 13)\). Then, \[\begin{eqnarray*}
5^{25} &=& 5 \times 5^{24}\\
&=& 5 \times (5^{12})^2\\
&\equiv& 5 \times 1^2 \modu 13) \hspace{3cm} \mbox{since} \, 5^{12} \equiv 1 \, \modu 13)\\
&\equiv& 5 \modu 13)
\end{eqnarray*}\] So, the principal remainder on dividing \(5^{25}\) by \(13\) is \(5\).
In the notation of FLT let \(p=7\) and \(a = 17\). Now, \(7 \nmid 17\), so by FLT we have that \(17^{6} \equiv 1 \modu 7)\). Then, \[\begin{eqnarray*}
17^{44} &=& 17^2 \times 17^{42}\\
&=& 17^2 \times (17^{6})^7\\
&\equiv& 17^2 \times 1^7 \modu 7) \hspace{3cm} \mbox{since} \, 17^{6} \equiv 1 \, \modu 7)\\
&\equiv& 3^2 \modu 7) \hspace{4cm} \mbox{since} \, 17 \equiv 3 \, \modu 7)\\
&\equiv& 9 \modu 7)\\
&\equiv& 2 \modu 7)
\end{eqnarray*}\] So, the principal remainder on dividing \(17^{44}\) by \(7\) is \(2\).
In the notation of FLT let \(p=11\) and \(a = 19\). Now, \(11 \nmid 19\), so by FLT we have that \(19^{10} \equiv 1 \modu 11)\). Then, \[\begin{eqnarray*}
19^{53} &=& 19^3 \times 19^{50}\\
&=& 19^3 \times (19^{10})^5\\
&\equiv& 19^3 \times 1^5 \modu 11) \hspace{3cm} \mbox{since} \, 19^{10} \equiv 1 \, \modu 11)\\
&\equiv& 8^3 \modu 11) \hspace{4cm} \mbox{since} \, 19 \equiv 8 \, \modu 11)\\
&\equiv& (-3)^3 \modu 11) \hspace{3.5cm} \mbox{since} \, 8 \equiv -3 \, \modu 11)\\
&\equiv& -27 \modu 11)\\
&\equiv& 6 \modu 11)
\end{eqnarray*}\] So, the principal remainder on dividing \(19^{53}\) by \(11\) is \(6\).








Question 8.5


Show that \(2^{11, 213} - 1\) is not divisible by 11.





Show Solution 8.5




Solution 8.5


We can use Fermat’ Little Theorem to solve this. Recall what the theorem says:

If \(p\) is prime, \(a \in \Z\) and \(p\) does not divide \(a\), then \(a^{p-1} \equiv 1 \modu p)\).

Let \(p = 11\) and \(a = 2\). Now 11 does not divide 2, so we can use FLT and \[2^{11-1} = 2^{10} \equiv 1 \modu 11).\] Now \[\begin{eqnarray*}
2^{11,213} - 1 &=& 2^3 (2^{11,210}) - 1\\
&=& 8 (2^{10})^{1121} - 1\\
&\equiv&8 (1)^{1121} - 1 \; \modu 11)\\
&\equiv&8 - 1 \; \modu 11)\\
&\equiv& 7 \modu 11).
\end{eqnarray*}\]
So, \(2^{11,213} - 1\) leaves principal remainder 7 on division by 11.
Note that 11,213 is prime and it can be shown that \(2^{11,213} - 1\) is prime. Primes of the form \(2^p - 1\) are called Mersenne primes. The largest known prime is a Mersenne prime; discovered in 2017 it is \(2^{77,232,917} - 1\) and has 23,249,425 digits.







Question 8.6


Find the inverses of 16, 17 and 18 in \(\Z^{\times}_{19}\). Use those results, together with Wilson’s Theorem, to find the remainder when 15! is divided by 19.





Show Solution 8.6




Solution 8.6


\(\Z^{\times}_{19} = \{1, 2, 3, \ldots , 16, 17, 18\}\). We know from the proof of Wilson’s Theorem that in \(\Z^{\times}_p\), where \(p\) is prime, the self-inverse elements are 1 and \(p-1\). So, the inverse of 18 in \(\Z^{\times}_{19}\) is 18 (which, of course, is equivalent to \(-1 \modu 19)\)).
Now, \(17^{-1} = 9\) since \(17 \times 9 = 153\) and \(153 \equiv 1 \modu 19)\).
Similarly, \(16^{-1} = 6\).
Recall that Wilson’s Theorem states that if \(p\) is prime then \((p-1)! \equiv -1 \modu p)\). So, with \(p=19\) we have \(18! \equiv -1 \modu 19)\).\\ Now, using the above results, \[\begin{eqnarray*}
15! &=& 18! \times 18^{-1} \times 17^{-1} \times 16^{-1}\\
&\equiv& (-1) \times (-1) \times 9 \times 6 \modu 19)\\
&\equiv& 54 \modu 19)\\
&\equiv& 16 \modu 19)
\end{eqnarray*}\] Hence, the principal remainder is 16.







Question 8.7


Let \(p\) be a prime except 2 and 5. Deduce from Fermat’s Little Theorem that there is a multiple of \(p\), all of whose digits in decimal notation are 9’s.
[Example: \(142857\times 7=999999\).]





Show Solution 8.7




Solution 8.7


Note that \(999 \ldots 9 = 10^k - 1\) for some \(k \in \Z\). So, \[\begin{eqnarray*}
np = 999 \ldots 9 &\Leftrightarrow& 10^k - 1 = np\\
&\Leftrightarrow& 10^k \equiv 1 \,\modu p)
\end{eqnarray*}\] Now, \(p \neq 2\) and \(p \neq 5\), hence \(10\) is not a multiple of \(p\), that is \(p \, \nmid \,10\). Hence, by FLT, \(10^{p-1} \equiv 1 \,\modu p)\) with \(p \neq 2, \, 5\). Then, with \(p=7\), say, \(10^6 \equiv 1 \, \modu 7)\) and so \(999,999 = 7n\) for some \(n\).







Question 8.8


Consider the set of Hilbert Numbers, \(\Sbb = \{ n \in \N \, | \, n \equiv 1 \modu 4) \}\). This is the set of all integers that are of the form \(4k + 1\), where \(k \in \N\). Find the first five ‘primes’ in this set (called Hilbert Primes). What is the smallest number in \(\Sbb\) that does not have a unique factorisation in Hilbert Primes?






Show Solution 8.8




Solution 8.8


First, it helps to visualise what numbers are actually in the set. Since we are going to be looking at primes in the set we need only consider members of \(\Sbb\) that are positive. So \[\Sbb = \{1, 5, 9, 13, 17, 21, 25, 29, 33, 37, \ldots \}.\]
We then need a suitable definition of ‘prime’ within the context of this set. If we use our usual definition for primes in \(\N\), we need to be careful that we refer to divisibility within the set. So, we define a Hilbert prime as a member of \(\Sbb\) greater than 1 that is divisible only by 1 (which is in \(\Sbb\)) and itself. Then, the first five Hilbert primes are 5, 9, 13, 17 and 21. Note that 9 and 21 are both divisible by 3 in \(\Z\), but 3 is not in \(\Sbb\).
Like the case of \(\E\) in the lectures, the unique factorisation principle in \(\N\) breaks down in \(\Sbb\). The first number in \(\Sbb\) to exhibit multiple prime factorisations is \[441 = 9 \times 49 = 21 \times 21.\]

title: 9  Rings and Fields
text:
9.1 Rings
In certain respects rings will probably seem more intuitive than groups since you have been using rings, and closely related structures, in your mathematical studies since primary school. On the other hand, though, the study of rings and fields is more complicated than the study of groups by virtue of the fact that we are now dealing with sets on which we are defining two binary operations, which we generally label addition and multiplication. Although we shall only be taking a cursory glance at these structures we shall be adopting an axiomatic approach, so we begin with a definition.
Strictly speaking we should denote a ring as \((R, +, \times)\) but, similarly to groups, we shall often simply refer to a ring as \(R\).
Note that the above definition can be summed up as: \((R, +, \times)\) is a ring if and only if \((R, +)\) is an abelian group which, along with the binary operation \(\times\), satisfies R6-R8.
Note, also, that whilst the axioms demand that the additive operation is commutative for any ring, there is no such requirement for the multiplicative operation. In the case where the ring \(R\) has \(ab=ba \; \forall \, a, b \in R\) we say that \(R\) is a commutative ring.
The following should be very familiar to everyone.

title: 9  Rings and Fields
text:
Definition 9.1 (Ring) A ring is a triple consisting of a non-empty set \(R\) equipped with two binary operations that we denote + and \(\times\), such that the following are satisfied.

R1:

For all \(a, b \in R\), \(a+b \in R\) (closure under +).

R2:

For all \(a, b, c \in R\), \((a+b)+c=a+(b+c)\) (+ is associative on \(R\)).

R3:

There exists \(0_R\) such that, \(\forall \, a \in R, a+0_R=0_R+a=a\) (+ has an identity).

R4:

For all \(a \in R, \, \exists \, -a \in R\) such that \(a+(-a)=(-a)+a=0_R\) (inverses under +).

R5:

For all \(a, b \in R\), \(a+b=b+a\) (+ is commutative on \(R\)).

R6:

For all \(a, b \in R\), \(ab \in R\) (closure under \(\times\)).

R7:

For all \(a, b, c \in R\), \(((ab)c=a(bc)\) (\(\times\) is associative on \(R\)).

R8:

For all \(a, b, c \in R\), \(a(b+c)=ab+ac\) and \((a+b)c=ac+bc\) (distributive laws).







Example 9.1 The following are rings:

\[\C, \R, \Q, \Z, \Z_{n}, \R_{2\times 2}.\]
The natural numbers do not form a ring as \((\N,+)\) is not a group (it is not closed under inverses).




Theorem 9.1 If \(R\) is a ring with additive identity \(0_R\) then, for any \(a, b \in R\), we have

\(0_Ra = a0_R = 0_R\),
\(a(-b) = (-a)b = -(ab)\),
\((-a)(-b) = ab\).



Proof. 

We take each in turn.

We have \[0_{R}a = (0_R + 0_R)a = 0_Ra + 0_{R}a.\] By cancellation (\((R,+)\) is a group) we deduce that \(0_{R}a = 0_{R}\). A similar argument demonstrates that \(a0_{R} = 0_{R}\).
It suffices to show that \(ab+ a(-b) = ab + (-a)b = 0_{R}\) since \((\R,+)\) is an abelian group and inverses are unique. We have: \[ ab + a(-b) = a(b + (-b))= a0_R = 0_R\] where the last equality follows from i.. One can similarly show that \(ab + (-a)b = 0_{R}\).
We have by ii. that \(-(a(-b))= (-a)(-b)\). Again by ii., \(a(-b) = -(ab)\). Therefore, \[(-a)(-b) = -(a(-b)) = -(-(ab)) = ab\] using the fact that \(-(-(ab)) = ab\) since \((\R,+)\) is a group.




9.1.1 Identity Elements
An identity element in a ring, \(R\), is a multiplicative identity. Hence, an identity element \(1_R \in R\) is such that \(a1_R = 1_Ra = a\) for all \(a \in R\). We assume that all of the rings that we encounter in this chapter have multiplicative identities. A ring with an identity element is sometimes referred to as a ring with a one.


9.1.2 Subrings
The concept of a subring is the same, in principle, as the concept of a subgroup. A subset of a ring \(R\) forms a subring of \(R\) if and only if it is a ring in its own right. As with groups, we have tests for whether or not a subset of \(R\) forms a subring and that is the subject of the following theorem.

Let \(R\) be a ring and let \(S \subseteq R\). Then \(S\) is a subring of \(R\) if and only if the three conditions below are satisfied:

\(S\) has an identity element;
\(a, b \in S \, \imp \, a-b \in S\);
\(a, b \in S \, \imp \, ab \in S\)



Proof. Let \(R\) be a ring and let \(S\) be a subset of \(R\).
\((\imp)\) First we show that if \(S\) is a subring of \(R\) then the three conditions hold.

As \(S\) is a subring then \(1_S \in S\) by definition (all our rings have a one).
Now let \(a, b \in S\). Since \(S\) is a ring it must be closed under addition. Further there is an additive inverse for \(b\) in \(S\) (R4) and since additive inverses are unique in \(R\) this inverse is the same as \(-b\) in \(R\). Hence \(a-b = a+(-b) \in S\).
Similarly, \(S\) is closed under multiplication.

\((\limp)\) Next we show that if \(S\) satisfies the three enumerated conditions then it is a subring of \(R\), that is, \(S\) is a ring in itself with the operations on \(S\) being defined as the operations on \(R\).
By i. \(S\) is non-empty.
Since \(S\) is non-empty, let \(a \in S\). By ii., \(a-a \in S\) and so \(0_R \in S\). We claim that \(0_R\) is an additive identity for \(S\). For any \(s \in S\), we have \(0_R+s=s\), since \(s \in R\) and since \(0_R\) is the additive identity in \(R\). Thus \(0_R\) is an additive identity for \(S\).
Let \(a \in S\). Then, by ii. we have \(0_S-a \in S\). But \(0_S-a=0_S+(-a)\), where \(-a\) is the additive inverse of \(a\) in \(R\). So \(-a \in S\) and \(-a\) is an additive inverse for \(a\) in \(S\).
Let \(a, b \in S\). Then \(-b \in S\) and \(-(-b)=b\), since if \(-b\) is an additive inverse for \(b\), then \(b\) is an additive inverse for \(-b\). Thus, \(a+b=a-(-b) \in S\), by ii., so \(S\) is closed under addition.
Let \(a, b \in S\). Then \(a+b \in S\) as \(S\) is closed under addition and, since \(a, b \in R\), we have \(a+b=b+a\) by commutativity of addition in \(R\).
Let \(a, b, c \in S\). Then, since \(a, b, c \in R\), we have that \(a+(b+c)=(a+b)+c\) and closure ensures that these sums are in \(S\).
Let \(a, b, c \in S\). Since \(a, b, c \in R\) then \(a(bc)=(ab)c\) in \(R\) and since \(S\) is closed under multiplication then \(a(bc)=(ab)c\) in \(S\).
By assumption \(S\) has a multiplicative identity \(1_{S}\).

Note that this theorem ensures that in any ring \(R\), both \(\{0_R\}\) and \(R\) itself are subrings of \(R\).






Caution



Let \(R\) be a ring and \(S\) be a subring of \(R\). Then it is not necessarily the case that \(1_{S} = 1_{R}\). For example Let \(R = \Z\). Then \(S = \{0\}\) is a subring of \(R\) however \(1_S = 0 \ne 1 = 1_{R}\).



Let \(R\) be a ring. The centre of \(R\) is denoted and defined by \[Z(R) = \{ a \in R \where ab=ba \, \forall \, b \in R \}.\] Prove that \(Z(R)\) is a subring of \(R\).

Solution:
First observe that \(Z(R)\) is non-empty since it contains \(1_{R}\). Note that \(1_R\) is therefore also the identity element of \(Z(R)\).
Let \(a,b \in Z(R)\) and \(r \in R\). Then, \[(a-b)r = ar - br = ra -rb = r(a-b)\] and \[(abr) = a(br) = (ar)b = r(ab).\] Therefore \((a-b),ab \in Z(R)\) as well. We conclude that \(Z(R)\) is a subring of \(R\).


It is important to be careful when considering the identity element in a subring given that there are two binary operations to take into account. Recall that the identity element in a ring is the multiplicative identity; the definition of a ring takes care of the additive identity \(0_R\). We know that \(S=(\{0_R\}, +, \times)\) is a subring of \(R\), but does it have a multiplicative identity?
Unlike groups, the identity in a subring does not have to be the same as the identity in the ring itself.


Let \(R = \Z_{6}\). The identity element in \(1\) since for all \(a \in \Z_{6}\), \(1a = a1 = 1\).
Now take \(S = \{0,2,4\}\). Then \(S\) is a subring of \(R\) (this is an exercise). However, the identity element is \(4\) since \[\begin{eqnarray*}
4 \times 0 &=& 0 \\
4 \times 2 & =& 2 \\
4 \times 4 &=& 4.
\end{eqnarray*}\]




9.1.3 Ring Homomorphisms

Definition 9.2 (Ring Homomorphism) Let \(R_1\) and \(R_2\) be rings and let \(\theta : R_1 \rightarrow R_2\) be a mapping. Then \(\theta\) is a ring homomorphism if, for all \(a, b \in R_1\) \[\theta (a+b) = \theta (a) + \theta (b)\] and \[\theta (ab) = \theta (a) \theta (b).\]

So, the definition is analogous to that for groups save that we have to consider both binary operations. Note that the first condition is simply the statement that \(\theta\) is a homomorphism mapping from the abelian group \((R_1, +)\) to the abelian group \((R_2, +)\). The second condition requires that \(\theta\) relates the multiplicative structures in the same way.

Let \(R_1\) and \(R_2\) be rings and let \(\theta : R_1 \rightarrow R_2\) be a ring homomorphism. Then,

\(\theta (0_{R_1}) = 0_{R_2},\)
\(\theta (-x) = - \theta (x)\) for all \(x \in R_1\).



Proof. 


We have \[\theta(0_{R_1}) = \theta(0_{R_1} + 0_{R_1}) = \theta(0_{R_1}) + \theta(0_{R_1}).\] Subtracting \(\theta(0_{R_1})\) from both sides, we have: \[\theta_{0_{R_1}} = 0_{R_2}.\]
We have \[0_{R_2}=\theta(0_{R_1}) = \theta(x + (-x)) =\theta(x) + \theta(-x).\] Using the fact that \((R_2, +)\) is a group (and so inverses are unique) we conclude that \(\theta(-x) = -\theta(x)\) as required.




Consider the mapping \(\theta : \Z \rightarrow \Z_n\) where \(\theta\) is defined by \(\theta (a)\) is the principal remainder on dividing \(a\) by \(n\) for all \(a \in \Z\). This is a ring homomorphism.

Let \(a, b \in  \Z\). Let \(0 \le r_1,r_2 \le n\) and \(q_1, q_2 \in \Z\) such that \(a = q_1 n + r_1\) and \(a_2 = q_2 n + r_2\). Notice that \(r_1\) and \(r_2\) are the principal remainders of \(a\) and \(b\) (respectively) upon dividing by \(n\).
Observe that \[a+b  = (q_1 + q_2)n + (r_1 + r_2)\] and \[ab = (q_1q_2n + q_1 r_2 + q_2 r_1)n + r_1 r_2.\]
We can find \(s,t  \in \{0,1,\ldots, n-1\}\) and \(u,v \in \Z\) such that \(r_1 + r_2 = u n + s\) and \(r_1 r_2 = vn + t\). Notice that the principal remainders of \(a+b\) and \(ab\) upon dividing by \(n\) are \(s\) and \(t\) respectively. Furthermore, in \(\Z_n\) we have \(r_1 + r_2 = s\) and \(r_1r_2 = t\). Therefore, \[\theta(a+b) = s = \theta(a) + \theta(b)\] and \[\theta(ab) = t = \theta(a) \theta(b).\]


As we did for group homomorphisms, we can define the kernel of a ring homomorphism:

Definition 9.3 (Kernel) Let \(R_1\) and \(R_2\) be rings and let \(\theta : R_1 \rightarrow R_2\) be a ring homomorphism. The kernel of \(\theta\) is the set denoted and defined by \[\text{ker} \, (\theta) = \{ x \in R_1 \where \theta(x) = 0_{R_2} \}.\]

Note here that it is the set of elements of \(R_1\) that map to the additive identity in \(R_2\). As with groups, an isomorphism is a bijective homomorphism. Where the ring isomorphism maps from a set to itself we refer to this as an automorphism.

title: 9  Rings and Fields
text:
9.2 Integral Domains

Definition 9.4 (Divisor of Zero) Let \(R\) be a ring with a one and let \(x \in R\) be non-zero. Then \(x\) is a divisor of zero in \(R\) if there exists \(y \in R \backslash \{0_{R}\}\) such that \(xy=0_R\).




\(\R\) is a ring with no zero divisors.
\(R=\R_{2 \times 2}\) is a ring with zero divisors. For example let \(x,y \in \R\backslash\{0\}\). Then \[A = \begin{pmatrix}0 & x \\ 0 & 0\end{pmatrix},B =\begin{pmatrix}0 & y \\ 0 & 0\end{pmatrix}\] are nonzero elements of \(\R_{2 \times 2}\). However \[AB = 0_{R} = \begin{pmatrix}0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0\end{pmatrix}.\]



We now make the following definition:

Definition 9.5 (Integral Domain) An integral domain is a nonzero commutative ring with a one in which there are no divisors of zero.

It follows from this definition that in an integral domain \(R\) we have \[xy = 0_R \imp x = 0_R \; \text{or} \; y=0_R.\]



\(\Z_{12}\) is a ring but it is not an integral domain For instance \[2 \times 6 = 0\] but \(2 \ne 0 \ne 6\).
Notice that \(\Z_{p}\) is an integral domain for any prime \(p\).




Theorem 9.2 In the ring \(\zn\) the divisors of zero are precisely those non-zero elements that are not relatively prime to \(n\).


Proof. 

Let \(r \in \Z_{n}\) be a nonzero element and suppose that \(d = \gcd(m,n) \ne 1\). Let \(k,l \in \Z\) be such that \(m = dk\) and \(n = dl\). Thus, \(lm = ldk = nk\). It follows that \(lm \equiv 0 \pmod{n}\). Notice that \(0 < l <n\) (since \(1< d\)) and so \(m\) is a divisor of \(0\) in \(\Z_n\).
On the other hand, suppose that \(r \in \Z_n\) is a zero divisor. By assumption \(r \ne 0\) and there exist some \(s \ne 0\) such that \(sr \equiv 0 \pmod{n}\). This means there is a \(q \in \Z\) such that \(sr =  qn\). If \(r\) and \(n\) are relatively prime, then \(n|s\) since \(n|sr\) by Corollary 8.3. It follows that \(s = 0\) which is a contradiction. We conclude that \(n\) and \(r\) are not relatively prime.



Corollary 9.1 If \(p\) is prime then \(\Z_p\) has no divisors of zero.


Proof. This follows directly from Theorem 9.2.

title: 9  Rings and Fields
text:
9.3 Division Rings
In a ring there is no requirement for any element to have a multiplicative inverse, so if a ring does have multiplicative inverses this makes the ring special. Recall from group theory that when we considered \(\zn\) under multiplication we were unable to form a group unless we ejected all of the elements not relatively prime to \(n\). This is tantamount to discarding all of the elements that do not have a multiplicative inverse in the set

Definition 9.6 (Unit) Let \(R\) be a ring. If \(a \in R\) has a multiplicative inverse in \(R\), then \(a\) is said to be a unit in \(R\).

We can collect together such units from a given ring, place them in a set and we obtain a group under multiplication.



The units of \(\Z\) are \(\{-1,1\}\) — this forms a group isomorphic to \(\Z_{2}\).
The units of \(\R_{2 \times 2}\) is precisely the group \(GL(2,\R)\).




Definition 9.7 (Division Ring) A division ring is a (not necessarily commutative) ring in which every non-zero element is a unit.

Hence, for all \(a \in R, \, a \neq 0\), there exists \(a^{-1} \in R\) such that \(aa^{-1}=a^{-1}a=1_R\).

Let \(R\) be a division ring. Then \((R\backslash \{0_{R} \}, \times)\) is a group.



Let \(\Hbb \subseteq \C_{2 \times 2}\) be the set \[\Hbb = \left\{ \begin{pmatrix}z & w \\ -\overline{w} & \overline{z}\end{pmatrix} : z,w \in \C\right\}.\]
We show that \(\Hbb\) is a subring of \(\C_{2 \times 2}\).
Note that \(\Hbb\) is non-empty, in particular it contains the identity matrix \(I_2\) (take \(z =1\) and \(w = 0\)).
Let \[A = \begin{pmatrix} z_1 & w_1 \\ -\overline{w}_1 & \overline{z}_1 \end{pmatrix}, B = \begin{pmatrix} z_2 & w_2 \\ -\overline{w}_2 & \overline{z}_2 \end{pmatrix} \in \Hbb.\] Then,
\[\begin{eqnarray*}
A-B &=& \begin{pmatrix} z_1 - z_2 & w_1 - w_2 \\ -\overline{w}_1 + \overline{w}_2 & \overline{z}_1 - \overline{z}_2 \end{pmatrix} \\
&=& \begin{pmatrix} z_1 - z_2 & w_1 - w_2 \\ -(\overline{w_1 - w_2}) & \overline{z_1 - z_2} \end{pmatrix} \in \Hbb
\end{eqnarray*}\]
and
\[\begin{eqnarray*}
    AB &=& \begin{pmatrix}z_1 z_2 - w_1\overline{w}_2 & z_1w_2  + w_1 \overline{z}_2 \\ -(\overline{w}_1 z_2 + \overline{z}_{1}\overline{w_2}) & -\overline{w}_1w_2 + \overline{z}_1\overline{z}_2\end{pmatrix} \\
    &=& \begin{pmatrix}z_1 z_2 - w_1\overline{w}_2 & z_1w_2  + w_1 \overline{z}_2 \\ -(\overline{z_1w_2  + w_1 \overline{z}_2}) & \overline{z_1z_2-w_1\overline{w}_2} \end{pmatrix} \in \Hbb.
\end{eqnarray*}\]
We now show that \(\Hbb\) is a division ring. Let \[A = \begin{pmatrix} z & w \\ -\overline{w} & \overline{z} \end{pmatrix} \in \Hbb\] be a non-zero element. Note that \(A^{-1}\) must be precisely the inverse of \(A \in \C_{2 \times 2}\) since \(I_2\) is the identity element of \(H\). Therefore, to show that \(H\) is a division ring, it suffices to show that \(A^{-1} \in H\). First we determine if \(A\) is invertible in \(\C_{2\times 2}\). We compute \[\det{A} = z\overline{z} + w \overline{w} = |z|^2 + |w|^2.\] Since \(A\) is nonzero, then one of \(z\) or \(w\) is nonzero and so \(|z|^2 + |w|^2 \ne 0\). Therefore \(A\) has a multiplicative inverse \(A^{-1} \in \C_{2\times 2}\) given by
\[A^{-1} = \frac{1}{\det{A}}\begin{pmatrix} \overline{z} & -w \\ \overline{w} & z \end{pmatrix}.\]
Since \(\det(A) \in \R\), it follows that \(\left(\overline{\frac{1}{\det{A}}}\right) = \frac{1}{\det{A}}\) and so \(A^{-1} \in \Hbb\).
Every non-zero element of \(\Hbb\) is a unit and so \(\Hbb\) is a division ring.


Where have we seen something similar to this in our study of groups? Recall that we were able to represent complex numbers as matrices in the following way:

Let \[M = \left\{\begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ -b & a \end{pmatrix}: a,b \in \R, a^2 + b^2 \ne 0\right\}.\] We found that \((\C \backslash \{0\}, \times) \cong (M, \times)\) with an isomorphism \(\theta: M \to \C\backslash\{0\}\) by \[\theta\left(\begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ -b & a \end{pmatrix}\right)= a + ib.\]

In a similar way we can represent quaternions as matrices. Quaternions were developed by the Irish mathematician Hamilton to solve problems in mechanics in three-dimensional space. They are an ‘extension’ of the complex numbers in the following way:

Let \(i,j,k\) satisfy the rules \(i^2 = j^2 = k^{2} = ijk =  -1\), thus: \[\begin{eqnarray}
ij &=& k = -ji \\
jk &=& i = -kj \\
ki &=& j = -ik.
\end{eqnarray}\]
Set \(\widehat{\Hbb} := \{ a + bi + cj + dk : a,b,c,d, \in \R \}\). Then \(\widehat{\Hbb}\) is a division ring.

The quaternions form a ring \(\widehat{\Hbb}\) and the group \(Q_8\) lives inside that ring. In a similar way to our representation of complex numbers as matrices with real entries, we can represent quaternions as matrices with complex entries:

The ring \(\widehat{\Hbb}\) is isomorphic to the ring \[\Hbb = \left\{ \begin{pmatrix} z & w \\ - \overline{w} & \overline{z} \end{pmatrix} : w,z \in \C  \right\}.\] An isomorphism is the map \(\theta: \widehat{\Hbb} \to \Hbb\) where \[\theta(a + bi + cj + dk) = \begin{pmatrix} a + bi & c + di \\ -(c-di) & a-bi \end{pmatrix}.\] Notice that
\[\begin{eqnarray*}
\theta(1) &=& \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = - \theta(-1) \\
\theta(i) &=& \begin{pmatrix} i & 0 \\ 0 & -i \end{pmatrix} = - \theta(-i) \\
\theta(j) &=& \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 \\ -1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} = - \theta(-j)\\
\theta(k) &=& \begin{pmatrix} 0 & i \\ i & 0 \end{pmatrix}  = -\theta(-k)
\end{eqnarray*}\]
Thus we have a representation of the quarternion group \(Q_8\) as a subgroup of \(GL(2, \C)\) (invertible 2-by-2 matrices over the complex numbers).

Then, as we have seen, the set of all such matrices forms a subring of the ring of all \(2 \times 2\) matrices with entries from \(\C\). In fact, it forms a division ring.

title: 9  Rings and Fields
text:
9.4 Fields
Consider the previous example. Note that, for example \[\begin{pmatrix}0&1\\-1&0\end{pmatrix}, \;  \begin{pmatrix}i&0\\0&-i\end{pmatrix} \; \in \mathbb{H}.\] Now \[\begin{pmatrix}0&1\\-1&0\end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix}i&0\\0&-i\end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix}0&-i\\-i&0\end{pmatrix},\] But \[\begin{pmatrix}i&0\\0&-i\end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix}0&1\\-1&0\end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix}0&i\\i&0\end{pmatrix}.\]
So, \(\mathbb{H}\) is not commutative under multiplication. We are, though, interested in cases where we do have commutativity; this leads to the following definition:

Definition 9.8 (Field) A field is a commutative division ring.



The rings \(\Q, \R\) and \(\C\) are all fields; \(\Z\) is not a fields (it is not a division ring).



Let \(F\) be a field. Then \((F\backslash \{0_{R} \}, \times)\) is an abelian group. Thus a ring \(R\) is a field if \((R,+)\) and \((R\backslash{0_{R}},\times)\) are both abelian groups.


9.4.1 Properties of Fields

Every field is an integral domain.


Proof. 

Let \(F\) be a field. To show that \(F\) is a field it suffices to show that it has no zero divisors. Let \(x\in F \backslash \{0_{F}\}\) and suppose there is a \(y \in F\) such that that \(xy = 0_{F}\). Since \(F\) is a field, and \(x\) is nonzero \(x\) has a multiplicative inverse \(x^{-1} \in F\). Then, \[y  = 1_{F}y = (x^{-1}x)y = (x^{-1}) 0_{F} = 0_{F}.\] Thus \(F\) has no zero divisors: if a product \(xy = 0\), one of \(x\) or \(y\) must be zero.



Definition 9.9 (Characteristic) Let \(R\) be an integral domain. The characteristic of \(R\), denoted \(\text{char}\,(R)\), is the period of \(1_R\) in the group \((R, +)\). If \(1_R\) has infinite period in the group \((R, +)\) then we define \(\text{char}\,(R)=0\).




\(\chr(\R) = 0\);
\(\chr(\zn) = n\);
\(\chr(\Q) = 0\).




Let \(R\) be an integral domain. Then \(\text{char}\,(R)\) is either zero or a prime.


Proof. 

Suppose \(\chr(R) = m \ne 0\). Let \(k,l \in \N\) such that \(kl = m\). For a positive integer \(a\) write \(a1_{R}\) for the sum \(\sum_{i=1}^{a} 1_{R}\). Then \[m1 = kl(1_{R}) = (k1_{r})(l1_{r}) = 0_{R}.\]
Since \(R\) is an integral domain, it must be that either \(k1_{R} = 0_{R}\) or \(l1_{r} = 0_{R}\). Since \(m = \chr{R}\) and \(1 \le k,l \le m\), we conclude that either \(k =m\) or \(l =m\). Thus \(m\) is divisible only by itself and \(1\) — \(m\) is prime.


This leads to the conclusion that any field has a subfield that is isomorphic to either \(\Q\) or \(\Z_p\). We find that any field with characteristic \(p\) has a copy of \(\Z_p\) ‘inside it’, whilst any field with characteristic 0 has a copy of \(\Q\) ‘inside it’.


9.4.2 Field Extensions
Consider the polynomial \(x^2-2\) in \(\Q\). What happens if we try to factorise it?

\(x^2 -2 = (x + \sqrt{2})(x- \sqrt{2})\). However, \(\sqrt{2} \not\in \Q\) so \(x^2 -2\) is not factorisable in \(\Q\). One potential way to resolve this is to extend \(\Q\) to include all the irrational numbers.

This ‘field extension’ gives us the set of real numbers, \(\R\). In a similar way, consider the polynomial \(x^2+1\) in \(\R\).

\(x^2 +1 = (x + i)(x- i)\). However, \(i \not\in \R\) so \(x^2 +1\) is not factorisable in \(\R\). One potential way to resolve this is to extend \(\R\) to include all numbers of the form \(a+ib\) where \(a,b \in \R\).

Returning to the first example, one obvious question to ask is whether the extension of \(\Q\) to the whole of \(\R\) is the ‘smallest’ possible extension that makes \(x^2 -2\) factorisable. The answer is ‘no’.

Define a field \(\Q(\sqrt{2}) = \{a + b \sqrt{2} | a,b \in \Q\}\). Clearly \(\sqrt{2} \in \Q(\sqrt{2})\) and so \(x^2 -2\) can be factorised in \(\Q(\sqrt{2})\). Notationally we write \(\Q(\sqrt{2})| \Q\) to indicate that this is an extension of \(\Q\).
We can similarly extend \(\Q\) in order to factorise say \(x^2 -6\).






Aside



The field \(\Q(\sqrt{2})|\Q\) is a vector space over \(\Q\) with basis \((1, \sqrt{2})\).



Note that this extension is a field in its own right (see Problem Set 7) and sits inside \(\R\). In fact it is a subfield of \(\R\), but it is clearly not all of \(\R\).
Such extensions of \(\Q\) are known as algebraic number fields. We say that \(\sqrt{2}\) is an algebraic element in \(\Q(\sqrt{2}) \where \Q\) (and, indeed, in \(\R \where \Q)\) as it is a root of the equation \(x^2=2\). In a similar way, \(i\) is an algebraic element in \(\C \where \R\) as it is a root of the equation \(x^2=-1\). On the other hand, \(e\) is not an algebraic element in \(\R \where \Q\) since there is no polynomial with rational coefficients that has \(e\) as a root.
We are now beginning to stray into the beginnings of Galois theory, a beautiful area of mathematics that explores the connection between group theory and field theory. This tells us why there are general formulae for solving quadratics, cubics and quartics, but not for polynomials of degree five or greater. It also gives us a characterisation of the ratios of lengths that can be constructed using only straightedge and compasses, thus leading to an elegant insight into the theory of constructible regular polygons. In fact it can be argued that the work of Galois, all completed before the age of 21 when he died, saw the birth of Abstract Algebra as a coherent mathematical discipline.

title: 9  Rings and Fields
text:
9.5 Problem Sheet 9
Covers Chapter 9.




Question 9.1



An element \(a\) of a ring \(R\) is said to be if \(a^2 = a\). Show that a division ring contains exactly two idempotent elements.
If every element in a ring \(R\) is idempotent, show that any non-zero element \(x \in R\) has period 2 in the group \((R, +)\).
Show that any ring in which every element is idempotent is necessarily commutative.






Show Solution 9.1




Solution 9.1



Clearly, \(0^2_R = 0_R\).
Now let \(a \in R, \; a \neq 0_R\). We know that \(a^{-1}\) exists (division ring), so \[\begin{eqnarray*}
a^2 &=& a\\
\Leftrightarrow \quad \;\;\;\; aa &=& a\\
\Leftrightarrow \;\; aaa^{-1} &=& aa^{-1}\\
\Leftrightarrow \qquad \;\; a &=& 1_R.
\end{eqnarray*}\] Hence, \(0_R\) and \(1_R\) are the only idempotent elements.
We have \[\begin{eqnarray*}
2x &=& x + x\\
&=& (x+x)^2 \qquad \text{idempotent}\\
&=& x^2 + 2x + x^2\\
&=& x + 2x + x \qquad \text{idempotent}\\
&=& 4x\\
&=& 2x + 2x
\end{eqnarray*}\] Hence, \(2x = 0\) and so \(x + x = 0\). Thus, \(x\) has period 2 in \((R, +)\).
Let \(x, y \in R\). Now \[\begin{eqnarray*}
x+y &=& (x+y)^2 \qquad \text{idempotent}\\
&=& x^2 + xy + yx + y^2\\
&=& x + xy + yx + y\qquad \text{idempotent}\\
&=& x + y + (xy + yx) \qquad \text{commutativity of +}
\end{eqnarray*}\] Hence, \(xy + yx = 0\) and so \(xy = -(yx)\). But in part (b) we showed that any element in \((R, +)\) has period 2, which tells us that \(-(yx) = yx\). Therefore, \(xy = yx\).








Question 9.2


Let \[S=\Bigg\{\left(\begin{array}{cc} x & 0 \\ 0 & 0\end{array}\right) : x\in\mathbb{R}\Bigg\}.\]
Prove that \(S\) is a subring of \(M_{2}(\mathbb{R})\).
[Note that the \(S\) and \(M_{2}(\mathbb{R})\) each have identity elements but they are not the same]





Show Solution 9.2




Solution 9.2


The element \(\left(\begin{array}{cc} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0\end{array}\right)\) acts as an identity element in \(S\) as, for all \(\left(\begin{array}{cc} x & 0 \\ 0 & 0\end{array}\right)\in S\) we have
\[\left(\begin{array}{cc} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{cc} x & 0 \\ 0 & 0\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{cc} x & 0 \\ 0 & 0\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{cc} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{cc} x & 0 \\ 0 & 0\end{array}\right).\]
Now let \(A=\left(\begin{array}{cc} x & 0 \\ 0 & 0\end{array}\right),B=\left(\begin{array}{cc} y & 0 \\ 0 & 0\end{array}\right)\in S\). Then \[A-B=\left(\begin{array}{cc} x-y & 0 \\ 0 & 0\end{array}\right)\in S\] and \[AB=\left(\begin{array}{cc} xy & 0 \\ 0 & 0\end{array}\right)\in S.\] Hence \(S\) is a subring of \(M_{2}(\mathbb{R})\).







Question 9.3


In the lectures we said that \(\Q (\sqrt 2)\) is a subfield of \(\R\). Prove that \(\Q (\sqrt 2)\) is a field.





Show Solution 9.3




Solution 9.3


Before tackling a problem like this it is always helpful to have a strategy. Recall that a field is a commutative division ring and that a division ring is a (not necessarily commutative) ring in which every non-zero element is a unit. So, the strategy is to show that \(\QR\) is a ring (what’s the easy way?) and then demonstrate that it is commutative and that all non-zero elements have multiplicative inverses.
To show that \(\QR\) is a ring is straightforward if we note that \(\QR\) is a subset of \(\R\); all we need to do is show that \(\QR\) is a subring of \(\R\).

We have that \(1 = 1 + 0 \sqrt 2 \in \QR\) and clearly \(1\) acts as an identity element in \(\QR\).
Let \(x = a + b \sqrt 2,\; y = c + d \sqrt 2 \in \QR\), ; \(a, b, c, d \in \Q\). Then \[\begin{eqnarray*}
x - y &=& (a + b \sqrt 2) - (c + d \sqrt 2)\\
&=& a - c + (b-d) \sqrt 2 \; \in \QR \qquad \text{as $a-c, \; b-d \; \in \Q.$}
\end{eqnarray*}\] Hence, \(\QR\) is closed under subtraction.
Let \(x = a + b \sqrt 2,\; y = c + d \sqrt 2 \in \QR\), ; \(a, b, c, d \in \Q\). Then \[\begin{eqnarray*}
      xy &=& (a + b \sqrt 2)(c + d \sqrt 2)\\
      &=& (ac +2bd) + (ad + bc) \sqrt 2 \; \in \QR \qquad \text{as $ac+2bd, \; ad+bc \; \in \Q.$}
      \end{eqnarray*}\] Hence, \(\QR\) is closed under multiplication.

Thus, by i. to iii. above, \(\QR\) is a subring of \(\R\) and, hence, a ring.
As mentioned, to now show that \(\QR\) is a field, we need to demonstrate that it is commutative and that every non-zero element is a unit.
Clearly commutativity follows from the fact that \(\QR\) is a subset of \(\R\), and \(\R\) is commutative.
Checking that each non-zero element is a unit needs care — we require that all non-zero elements of \(\QR\) have an inverse in \(\QR\).
It is useful, for illustration purposes, to consider a specific, numerical example. Suppose that we consider \(1 + 2 \sqrt2 \in \QR\). Now consider the conjugate \(1 - 2 \sqrt 2 \in \QR\). Then \[(1 + 2 \sqrt2)(1 - 2 \sqrt2) = 1^2 - (2 \sqrt2)^2 = 1 - 8 = -7.\] Now, it follows that \((1 + 2 \sqrt2)(1 - 2 \sqrt2)(-\frac{1}{7}) = 1\) and, hence, we have that \[(1 + 2 \sqrt2)^{-1} = \left(-\frac{1}{7}\right)(1 - 2 \sqrt2) = \frac{1}{(1^2 - (2\sqrt2)^2)}(1 - 2 \sqrt2).\] Checking:
\[\begin{eqnarray*}
(1 + 2 \sqrt2)\left(-\frac{1}{7} + \frac{2 \sqrt 2}{7}\right) &=& -\frac{1}{7} + \frac{2}{7}\sqrt2 - \frac{2}{7}\sqrt2 + \frac{4 \sqrt2}{7}\sqrt2\\
&=& -\frac{1}{7} + \frac{8}{7}\\
&=& \frac{7}{7}\\
&=& 1
\end{eqnarray*}\]
We now consider the general case. Let \(0 \neq x = a + b \sqrt2 \in \QR\). Consider the conjugate \(y = a - b\sqrt2 \in \QR\). Then \((a + b\sqrt2)(a - b\sqrt2) = a^2 - 2b^2 \in \Q\). So, in order to get the identity, \(1\), from \(x\), we simply need to multiply \(x\) by \[\frac{1}{a^2 - 2b^2}(a - b\sqrt2) \in \QR.\] But, could \(a^2 - 2b^2 = 0\)?
It is easy to see that the only solution to the equation \(a^2 - 2b^2 = 0\), with \(a, b \in \Q\) is \(a=b=0\). Hence, for all \(0 \neq x = a + b\sqrt2 \in \QR\) then \(a^2 = 2b^2 \neq 0\) and we have \[x^{-1} = \frac{1}{a^2 - 2b^2}(a - b \sqrt2) \in \QR, \;\;\; \forall \, x \in \QR.\] So, \(\QR\) is a field.
